One could quite naturally observe her

68. This Woman’s soul seemed to submit
to worry and fear that her little one,
finding her milk, would suck her blood
along with the dead milk. Thus, by all accounts,
this artful Picture was so famous
that no less than the great Alexander,
because it gave him such delight,
had it carried to his native City of Pellas.

69. This face may well have had the mouth
open on one side, just as we have described
a demeanor pertaining to sorrow:
the forehead’s wrinkles pressing against each other,
the eyebrows raised unevenly,
the flesh color fading with approaching death,
a blush of pale purple on lip and cheek,
staring fixedly at the child with grieving eyes.
left-middleEstimation of how this must have been depicted.

70. To do much more with this matter
one must descend into deeper caves,
far from here, somewhere near the Cimmerians,
where the Father of Morpheus has his empire,
and is wont to lie snoring as he dreams.
Then I greatly hope that this will kindle
many more spirits, and increase the desire
to better attend to the Emotions.

71. For these are (I think) very practical secrets,
which occur enough even in Art,
so that good Masters (I venture to say)
use them more than they know themselves;
indeed, being perfect in one skill, they are perfect in all.
Thus their works shall be far from belittled
by discerning viewers, whose deep insight
almost transforms illusion into reality, confirming it with praise.
left-middleDepicting emotions are used by the great Masters more than they know; for whoever is good in one aspect of painting, is good in all.

72. Thus Vasari remarked, writing
with his noble pen of Buonarotti,
that refined minds perceived in his Last Judgment
the sin for which each person rushed to Hell,
and that in painting the Emotions
no other Painter came before him;
but this remark is based on ignorance, or opinion,
and is contrary to Pliny.

73. He also said that Michelangelo could see
the nature of life, with penetrating senses,
from much observation of People in the World.
